document.docTitle: Bio-genetic analysis of resistance in tomato to early blight disease, Alternaria alternata

docTitle.paragraph: Bio-genetic analysis of resistance in tomato to early blight disease,

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Department of Biology , Falavarjan Branch , Islamic Azad University , Isfahan , 84517-31167, Iran

paragraph.emphasis: Plant Protection Research Division, Isfahan Center for Research and Education in Agricultural Science and Natural Resources, (AREEO), Isfahan , 81786-96446, Iran
Plant Biotechnology, Department of Biology, University of Isfahan , Isfahan , 81746-73441, Iran

collectionCode.name: Department of Botany, Swedish Museum of Natural History

subSection.paragraph:
Early blight disease (EB),
Alternaria alternata
, is destructive on
Solanum lycopersicum Mill.
The responses of 35 domestic and exotic commercial tomato genotypes to early blight were examined at transplanting and maturing stages using genetic diversity analysis, with 15 Inter Simple Sequence Repeat (ISSR) primers, total phenolic content (TPC), and enzymatic activity of catalase (CAT), phenylalanine ammonia lyase (PAL), peroxidase (POD) and superoxide dismutase (SOD) assays. The disease severity ranged from 18 to 87.5%. Eleven of 15 ISSR primers generated 68 loci of which 63 (90%) were polymorphic. Polymorphism information content value varied from 0.3 to 0.5 with an average of 0.4. Nei’ s measure of the average gene diversity ranged from 0.06 to 0.5. The Tomato genotypes were divided into five clusters in Un-weighted Pair Group Method with Arithmetic Mean (UPGMA) analysis, showing a considerable similarity between resistance level and molecular classification pattern. Antioxidant analysis indicated a significant increase in TPC and CAT, POD, PAL and SOD activities in most inoculated tomato genotypes at both growth stages. The highest increase in activity was seen in PAL (5- fold) and TPC (4-fold) at transplanting stage, whereas the highest TPC (2 to 3-fold) and POD activity (3-fold) were found at maturing stage in all the inoculated resistant genotypes in comparison with controls. Esfahan Local and H . a.s 2274 showed the highest level of activity in POD (2.5- and 3- fold, respectively) and TPC (2.5- and 4- fold, respectively). Our results suggest that using both genetic diversity and enzymatic diversity as markers, it is possible to discriminate resistant from susceptible tomato genotypes to early blight disease.
ISSR marker
Catalase
Phenylalanine ammonia lyase
Peroxidase
Superoxide dismutase

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: rezayatmand@iaufala.ac.ir (Z. Rezayatmand), mne2011@gmail.com, m.nasr@areeo.ac.ir (M.N. Esfahani).

subSection.paragraph:
This study was undertaken to identify levels and patterns of genetic variability and resistance of tomato genotypes for resistant to
A. alternate
, and to apply markers for the identification of resistant lines in tomato breeding programs.

emphasis.heading: 2.1. Disease severity evaluation of tomato genotypes caused by

subSection.paragraph:
The EB disease,
A. alternata
, severity analysis showed that all of the inoculated genotypes were infected under both greenhouse evaluation tests. The control plants (non-infected) were free of EB disease. In every growth stage, the inoculated genotypes exhibited varying severity responses to the disease ranging from 5 to 19% at transplanting stage and from 18 to 88% at maturing stage. These genotypes fell into 5 different categories in terms of the disease severity; highly susceptible (HS), susceptible (S), moderately susceptible (MS), moderately resistant (MR) and resistant (R). There was a significant difference in the percentage of the EB disease severity among tomato genotypes at transplanting and maturing stages (P < 0.01) ( Table 1 ).

At transplanting stage, EB disease screening of the inoculated tomato genotypes identified eight genotypes as resistant: H. a.s 2274, Esfahan local variety, Roma, Turkish Cherry, Valouro RZ , Long Tomato Y , Shiraz local variety and Falat American 111 (5–7%); the others were moderately resistant (8–20%). At maturing stage, the resistant genotypes were; Esfahan local, Turkish Cherry and Rio Grande (18–25%); the remaining genotypes varied in their response to the disease ranging from moderately resistant to highly susceptible (25–88%) ( Table 1 ).

The results showed that the greatest severity of the EB disease occurs mostly at the mature stage. The difference of EB disease severity was caused by genotype and growth stage; the interaction between these factors was significant at the 0.01 level. Overall, the results showed that H. a.s2274 and Esfahan local were resistant to
A . alternata
infection under both evaluation growth stages tests, while the majority of tomato genotypes varied from moderately to highly susceptible at both stages ( Table 1 ).

Cluster analysis of EB disease severity at both stages classified tomato genotypes into three main groups (I, II and III), which were consistent with the results of the LSD ( Fig. 1 ). The cluster results showed that the resistant tomato genotypes, Rio Grande, Turkish Cherry and Esfahan Local, belonged to the group (II), the highly susceptible tomato genotypes belonged to the group (III), and the moderately susceptible and moderately resistant belonged to group (I).

caption.paragraph:
The impact of tomato genotypes including genotype number, registered name, origin, properties, breeding company, disease severity and reaction to early blight disease cause by
Alternaria alternata .
(Continued).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Ward’ s clustering dendrogram of 35 tomato genotypes based on resistance to
Alternaria alternata
. Note: Cluster Ӏ consisted of moderately susceptible and moderately resistant genotypes, Cluster ӀӀ consisted of resistant genotypes and Cluster ӀӀӀ consisted of highly susceptible genotypes. Disease severity was assessed based on infection percent (0–100) against the scoring scales of: 0, 5, 10, 25, 50, 75, or 100%.

ISSR primers used for detecting polymorphism among tomato genotypes including: Primers, Sequence 5ʹ→3ʹ, Annealing Temperature, Total Band Number of Polymorphism Band, Polymorphism percent, Polymorphic Information Content, Marker Index, Effective Number of Allele, Nei’ s gene diversity and Shannon’ s Information Index.

paragraph.tableNote: Genomic DNA extraction from young leaf tissue.The PCR-based ISSR reaction mixes were prepared using 15 ISSR primers. The DNA amplifications were programmed in a 10-m initial denaturalization phase at 94 ◦ C followed by 45 cycles of annealing each lasting 45–60 s, at a primer-specific.The process continued with an extension phase at 72 ◦ C for 2 min and with a final extension phase at 72 ◦ C for 10 min when naturalization occurs. The PCR-amplified fragments were electrophoresed on 1.5% (w/v) agarose gels.

caption.paragraph: Pairwise Matrix of Nei’ s genetic distance between 35 tomato genotypes including susceptibility groups.

subSection.paragraph: Based on UPGMA analysis, these 35 genotypes were grouped into two major clusters: the first cluster including 111Falat American, and the second cluster including all other genotypes ( Fig. 2 ). According to the reference line, all genotypes divided into five clades as shown in Fig. 2 . The Cophenetic correlation coefficient based on Jaccard’ s similarity coefficient was 0.67, %, indicating a moderate fitness between the dendrogram and the relative efficiency. The similarity coefficient among these genotypes ranged from 0.36 to 0.93. The lowest similarity coefficient (0.36 and 0.44), which is indicative of the highest genetic diversity, was observed in 111Falat American and Roma, respectively, two moderately resistant genotypes. The fifth clade contained four resistant genotypes, Esfahan Local, Turkish Cherry, Rio Grande and H . a.s 2274 with 60%–88% similarities. The third clade contained four genotypes with the highest susceptibility ( CH American, Hedieh, Ameera and Izmir) with 80%–90% similarities. Although these results showed a distinct genetic divergence between the resistant and highly susceptible genotype clusters, the other genotypes did not show such a clear distinction and were distributed all over the clades ( Fig. 2 ). Principal component analysis (PCA), on 2D basis, showed a significant clustering of tomato genotypes that were plotted into five sub-plots, representing the significant genetic variation and differentiation among genotypes and their low genetic similarity ( Fig. 3 ). One group (green oval) was identical to the fifth clade using UPGMA, which were also clear in 3D

paragraph.tableNote: a G1 = highly susceptible group (CH American, Hyb. Retinto, Izmir, Ameera RZ, Hedieh, Super Crystal, Hyb. Sogno); G2 = susceptible group (111 Falat, Santawest Hyb., Supermobile, Shiraz local, Chief, Super Chief American, CH), G3 = moderately susceptible group (Hyb. Prolico, Hyb. Ventero, Chief Falat, Caribo, Hyb. Cherry., Hyb. Belize., Granisum Romani, Long Tomato Y, Hyb. SV 1201., H. a.s 2194); G4 = moderately resistant group (Roma, Falat American 111, Rayosol RZ, Italian Round, Arya Netherlands, Valouro RZ, Sakhia), G5 = resistant group (H.a.s 2274, Turkish Cherry, Rio Grande, Esfahan local).

Band Frequency, Number of Alleles, Effective Number of Allele, Shannon’ s information index, Expected Heterozygosity and Unbiased Expected Heterozygosity.

Hyb. Belize., Granisum Romani, Long Tomato Y, Hyb.SV 1201., H. a.s 2194); G4 = moderately resistant group (Roma, Falat American 111, Rayosol RZ, Italian Round,

subSection.paragraph:
The results from the analysis of specific enzymatic activity and the total phenol content at both growth stages showed significant changes in most of the inoculated tomato leaves in comparison with the controls ( Tables 6 and 7 ). At the transplanting stage, there was a significant increase in the CAT activity among all tomato genotypes in comparison with the controls, but the highest increase was observed in Esfahan Local (65.58 U∙mg 1 ), H . a.s 2274 (53.42 U∙mg 1 ), Caribo (53.45 U∙mg 1 ) and Shiraz Local (47.43 U∙mg 1 ) ( Table 6 ). At the maturing stage, Esfahan Local and H . a.s 2274 had the highest CAT activity (106.98 and 79.46 U∙mg 1 respectively) ( Table 7 ). The transplanting stage showed an increased level of specific POD activity in response to
A. Alternata
infection, while the highest level was observed in the resistant genotypes, H . a.s 2274 (116.46 U∙mg 1 ) and Shiraz Local variety (97.76 U∙mg 1 ) as compared with the controls ( Table 6 ).

The level of specific POD activity at the maturing stage was higher in the inoculated resistant genotypes, H . a.s 2274, Turkish Cherry, Rio Grande and Esfahan Local variety (340.74, 311.92, 268.06 and 258.66 U∙mg 1 , respectively) in comparison with the controls ( Table 7 ).

Here again, the transplanting stage showed a higher level of specific PAL activity in the inoculated resistant genotypes, Shiraz Local variety (6.96 U∙mg 1 ), H . a.s 2274 (5.45 U∙mg 1 ) and Esfahan Local variety (4.65 U∙mg 1 ) in comparison with the controls and the susceptible genotypes ( Table 6 ). Similarly, there was a significant increase in the PAL activity among inoculated resistant genotypes at the maturing stage ( Table 7 ). In the transplanting stage, all inoculated resistant genotypes showed a significant increase in the SOD activity, but the highest level of activity was observed in Shiraz Local and Esfahan Local (4.45, and 3.63 U∙mg 1 , respectively) in comparison with others ( Table 6 ). In the maturing stage, increased SOD activity was seen in all the inoculated genotypes, but the highest level was observed in H . a.s 2274, Turkish Cherry and Esfahan Local (9.02, 8.08 and 6.29 U∙mg 1 , respectively) ( Table 7 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Grouping of 35 tomato genotypes and lines using the UPGMA method based on complete algorithm and Jaccard’ s similarity coefficient of 11 ISSR molecular markers. G1 consisted of highly susceptible genotype, G2 consisted of susceptible genotype, G3 consisted of moderately susceptible genotype, G4 consisted of moderately resistant genotype and G5 consisted of resistant genotype. Pearson correlation analysis was carried out to analyze the relationship among the tomato genotypes and response variability and cluster analysis of data was performed using SPSS software.

Fig. 3. A two-dimensional plot of the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) of ISSR data showing the clustering of 35 tomato genotypes. On PCA plot, three groups are formed and two other genotypes, namely 111 Falat American and Roma, scattered on the plot and do not fall under any of the groups. The distribution of genetic variation within, and among, groups, was detected using the molecular variance analysis (AMOVA) in GenAlEx software. Genetic variation indices, including observed number of alleles (Na) and effective numbers of alleles (Ne), Shannon’ s information index (I), Nei’ s gene diversity (H), percent of polymorphic loci (PPL), were estimated using POP-GENE software.

Fig. 4. Three-dimensional PCA plot using ISSR data of 35 tomato genotypes. The distribution of genetic variation within, and among, groups, was detected using the molecular variance analysis in GenAlEx software. Genetic variation indices, including observed number of alleles and effective numbers of alleles, Shannon’ s information index, Nei’ s gene diversity, percent of polymorphic loci, were estimated using POP-GENE software.

subSection.paragraph: The transplanting stage showed a large amount of TPC in all inoculated tomato leaves ( 16–70 mg GAE/g f. wt) in comparison with the controls ( Table 6 ). The inoculated resistant genotypes, Shiraz Local, Esfahan Local and H . a.s 2274, contained much higher TPC (70.16, 69.25, 53.98 U∙mg 1 , respectively), than the susceptible genotypes ( Table 6 ). The level of TPC was significantly higher at the maturing stage in the infected plants in comparison with the controls ( 29–87 mg GAE/g f. wt). Esfahan Local, Turkish Cherry and H . a.s 2274 contained the highest value of TPC (87.62, 86.53 and 82.89, U∙mg 1 respectively) in comparison with the controls ( Table 7 ).

This is the first study on the genetic diversity of tomato exploring genetic resistance and biochemical changes in response to
A. alternata
infection using ISSR as genetic markers. Our findings support the conclusion that different tomato genotypes have different reactions to
A. alternata
at transplanting and maturing stages ( Nasr Esfahani et al., 2017a , 2017b ; Akhtar et al., 2019 ). Although there was a significant difference in resistance to EB disease among tomato genotypes at both growth stages, disease severity was more pronounced at the maturing stage. Highly infected genotypes at the maturing stage exhibit more resistance arising from the influence of plant age ( Vloutoglou and Kalogerakis, 2000 ; Adhikari et al., 2017 ; Nasr Esfahani, 2019 ).

According to our findings, only H . a.s 2274 and Esfahan local Variety were found to be resistant to
A. alternata
at both growth stages. The screening results of 172 recombinant inbred line population of tomato under field conditions by Foolad and Ashrafi (2015) showed a wide range of reactions in response to EB disease, from resistant to susceptible, and no lines were completely resistant. Akhtar et al. (2019) reported that out of 401 tested tomato genotypes, only one genotype was resistant. Our results corroborate previous studies, in which no tomato genotype was completely EB disease-resistant.

While our study found an average number of 6.18 bands per primer, Kiani and Siahchehreh (2018) found an average of 7.6 bands per ISSR primer on 12 tomato varieties using 9 primers. Using 9 primers on 96 tomato accessions, Aguilera et al. (2011) found an average of 14.4 bands per ISSR primer. Figueiredo et al. (2016) observed an average of 9.25 bands per ISSR primer using 10 primers on 10 tomato lines. The higher mean of the total bands as reported in these studies could be attributed to either the higher number of tomato genotypes or the higher number of primers. It is noteworthy that our results showed a higher average polymorphism percentage (86.82%), than those reported by Aguilera et al. (2011) (36.80%), Figueiredo et al. (2016) (34.02%), and Kiani and Siahchehreh (2018) (76.38%), suggesting a significant variation in our tomato genotypes.

The higher polymorphic and genetic diversity level found by our research is consistent with the report by Henareh et al. (2016) , except for H , which in our study yielded the following figures: (Ne = 1.46; H = 0.27; I = 0.42) in 35 genotypes of
S. lycopersicum
. Henareh et al. (2016) , studied the genetic diversity among 93 tomato landraces, using 14 primers, and obtained 185 bands with 100% polymorphism, Shannon index ( I ) of 0.37, Ne of 1.33.

caption.paragraph: Determination of Catalase (CAT), Peroxidase (POD), Phenylalanine Ammonia Lyase (PAL) and Superoxide Dismutase (SOD) specific activities and Total Phenol

Content (TPC) in inocul a ted tomato leaves compared to controls at transplant to early blight disease caused by
Alternaria alternata
.

tableNote.paragraph: a Comparative analysis of CAT, POD, PAL, and SOD activities and TPC in genotypes at 20 days post inoculation (dpi) at transplanting stage. U = 1 mmol of hydrogen peroxide∙min 1 of protein decreased by CAT, 1 mmol of tetraguaiacol or 1 μmol of trans-cinnamic per minute released by POD or PAL activities, respectively, and amount of enzyme required to inhibi b 50% of the NBT photoreduction∙min. Each value represents the mean of 3 replicates. Different letters indicate statistically significant differences (P ≤ 0.05).
b Control, non-inoculated tomato genotypes, c Treatment, inoculated tomato genotypes.

subSection.paragraph:
Pathogenesis-related proteins (PRs) have been found to enhance the defensive capacity of plants in necrotic infection ( Dey et al., 2019 ; van Esse et al., 2020 ). We have shown that in tomato, the increased expression of PR proteins, β-1,3-glucanase and chitinase, was related to the resistance response to
A. alternata
infection ( Moghaddam et al., 2019 ). In the present study, the enzyme activity analysis showed increased activity of enzymatic antioxidants, CAT, POD, PAL and SOD, in the inoculated tomato genotypes, suggesting possible contribution to plant defense response. Accumulation of CAT and SOD under disease conditions has been reported to promote plant defense responses ( Chung, 2012 ; w. Li et al., 2018 ). In our study, during infection with
A. alternata ,
the PAL (5-fold at transplanting stage) and POD (3-fold at maturing stage) enzyme activities were markedly increased in the inoculated resistant genotypes compared with the controls and susceptible genotypes. Thus, our findings supported the previous study of Li et al. (2018) that
A. alternata
infection significantly increased activities of POD and PAL enzymes.

Notably, a significant increase in TPC values was seen in all tomato genotypes during
A. alternata
infection. Higher TPC values were seen in inoculated resistant genotypes at both growth stages. These results clearly showed the involvement of TPC in the defense of tomato to EB disease. The highest TPC activity at transplanting stage (4-fold) and maturing stage (2 to 3-fold) were found in all the inoculated resistant genotypes as compared with their respective controls. These findings are consistent with previous studies ( Ayala-Zavala et al., 2012 ; w. Li et al., 2018 ), that have reported high level of phenols acting as damaging components in
A. alternata
infection.

In conclusion, the present study furthers our understanding of the significance of antioxidants and the extent of genetic diversity in 35
S. lycopersicum
genotypes in response to
A. alternata
infection. Based on EB disease-resistance levels and ISSR marker data, the 35 tomato genotypes were categorized into five major groups. Among all the inoculated genotypes, H . a.s 2274 and Esfahan local showed a significant resistance level, and increased antioxidant activities at both growth stages. Moreover, enhancement of antioxidants and enzymes production in the EB disease-resistance in tomato genotypes are important observations. Future research is needed to examine the relationship between genetic diversity and EB disease-resistance.

Thirty-five commercial genotypes of exotic and domestic origin, and inbred lines, were used ( Table 1 ). Untreated tomato seeds were placed in
July 2018
in seedling trays filled with sterilized mix of sand-peat moss in equal parts placed in a forced-air oven at 93 ◦ C for 30 min. They were kept in greenhouse conditions (27 ± 1 ◦ C), with 16 h-light photoperiod and 65% relative humidity. Nutrients to support plant growth were supplied through irrigation with Knop’ s nutrient solution ( 10 mg FeCl 3 ; 0.25 g KH 2 PO 4 ; 0.25 g KNO 3 ; 0.25 g MgSO 4 •7 H 2 O and 1 g NaNO 3 ∙L 1 of tap water) from Columbus Chemical Industries (Columbus, WI 53925) ( Nasr Esfahani et al., 2017b ).

Two seedlings of each genotype were transferred to 5 kg plastic pots filled with a sterilized soil, sand and peat moss (1:1:1) substrate at first fully expanded true leaf stage ( Nasr Esfahani et al., 2017b ; Nasr Esfahani, 2018b ). Screening was conducted at transplanting and maturing stages in the greenhouse, and biochemical and genetic assays carried out in the laboratory of the Agricultural and Natural Resources Research and Education center of Esfahan , Iran . The experiments were arranged in a completely randomized design with 3 replications and 10 plants of each genotype per replication.

heading.emphasis: 4.2. Fungal culture inoculum preparation and plant pathogenicity

caption.paragraph:
Quantification of Catalase (CAT), Peroxidase (POD), Phenylalanine Ammonia Lyase (PAL) and Superoxide Dismutase (SOD) specific activities, and Total Phenol Content controls at mature stage to Early Blight disease cause by
Alternaria alternata
.

tableNote.paragraph: a Activity of CAT activity, POD activity, PAL Activity, SOD activity and TPC in six genotypes in 20 days post inoculation (dpi) at transplanting stage. U:1 mmol of hydrogen peroxide per minute of protein decreased by CAT, 1 mmol of tetraguaiacol or 1 μmol of trans-cinnamic per minute liberated by POD or PAL activities, respectively, and the amount of enzyme required to inhibit 50% of th b NBT photo-reduction per minute. Each valu c represents the mean of three replicates. Different letters indicate statistically significant differences (P ≤ 0.05).

subSection.paragraph: Genomic DNA extraction from about 1 g of young leaf tissue (the 5–6 leaf stage) from each tomato genotype was carried out using a modified Cetyl Trimethyl Ammonium Bromide (CTAB) - based method according to Stewart and Via (1993) . The DNA quality and purity were determined using a Nano spectrophotometer. The PCR-based ISSR reaction mixes were prepared according to Zietkiewicz et al. (1994) using 15 ISSR primers (Macrogen Korea, South Korea ). The amplification reaction mix (25 μL) comprised 1 μL extracted DNA, 1.5 μL of 1 primer, 12.5 μL of 2x Master mix Red and 10 μL distilled water (Ampliqon, Odense, Denmark ). The DNA amplifications were performed using an Eppendorf Gradient Mastercycler (Eppendorf, Hamburg , Germany ). Amplification reactions were programmed in a 10-m initial denaturalization phase at 94 ◦ C followed by 45 cycles of annealing each lasting 45–60 s, at a primer-specific temperature ( Table 3 ). The process continued with an extension phase at 72 ◦ C for 2 min and with a final extension phase at 72 ◦ C for 10 min when naturalization occurs. The PCR-amplified fragments were electrophoresed on 1.5% (w/v) agarose gels, in the 1X TBE Buffer at 80 V for 1.5 h. A gene ruler 100 bp DNA ladder plus (RNA Biotech Co., Isfahan , Iran ) was used as a standard to determine size of polymorphic fragments, as visualized by ethidium bromide staining and photographed under UV light.

heading.emphasis: 4.4. Antioxidant activities and total phenolic contents analysis

subSection.paragraph: To estimate defense-related enzymes, 14 susceptible and resistant genotypes of tomato were selected based on screening ( Table 1 ). After re-inoculation at transplanting and mature stages, third leaves of the tomato genotypes from control, non-inoculated genotypes and inoculated groups were collected separately as samples and stored in aluminum foil at 80 ◦ C for enzyme extraction. All experiments were repeated 3 times ( Moghaddam et al., 2019 ).

Estimations of defense-related enzyme contents were done on extracts. To obtain CAT, POD, PAL and SOD extracts, pre-weighed infected and non-infected leaves were homogenized in 4 mL buffer [50 mM Tris pH = 8.5, 14.4 mM 2-mercaptoethanol and 1% (w/v) insoluble polyvinylpolypyrrorolidone]. Homogenates were centrifuged at 6000× g for 15 min at 4 ◦ C ( Jung et al., 2011 ). Total protein in each enzyme extract was determined through the Bradford procedure (1976) using bovine serum albumin as a standard. The method of Aebi (1984) was used to estimate CAT activity. The photometric intensity of the reaction was measured using a spectrophotometer ( 240 nm ) in a 10 mM hydrogen peroxide solution. The POD activity was determined by methods as described by Dazy et al. (2008) . The photometric intensity of the reaction was measured using a spectrophotometer ( 470 nm ) in a 40 mM hydrogen peroxide solution. The method of Beauchamp and Fridovich (1971) was used to estimate SOD activity. The photometric intensity of the reaction was measured using a spectrophotometer ( 560 nm ) with a 75 μM nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) and 1.5 μM riboflavin under 40-W fluorescent lamp at 25 ◦ C for 20 min. The PAL activity was assessed as described by Beaudoin-Eagan and Thorpe (1985) . The photometric intensity of the reaction was measured using a spectrophotometer ( 290 nm ) with 15 mM phenylalanine as the substrate. The TPC of each sample extract was determined with the Folin-Ciocalteu reagent by the method of Singleton et al. (1999) . The photometric intensity of the reaction was measured using a spectrophotometer ( 760 nm ) using gallic acid as the substrate.
